titleStmt.title: To WILLIAM DARE MORGAN,William Dare Morgan (1838-87), son of CD’s friend Captain Elisha Ely Morgan (?1805-64). Joined his father’s shipping firm, the Black X Line, and spent most of the period 1861-4 in London, safeguarding the family’s interests during the American Civil War. See Leon Litvack, 'Messages from the Sea: New Dickens Letters to E.E. and W.D. Morgan', Dickensian 110.2 (2014), 242-54. 13 March 1863

dateline.placeName: OFFICE OF ALL THE YEAR ROUND,

body.p: I should not find it easy to tell you if I tried – and I am not going to try – how very much obliged to you I feel for your prompt assistance and sound good sense in the matter of Frank.Francis Jeffrey Dickens (1844-86), CD's son. I do not write for any such impracticable purpose, but merely to advise you that Charley will give you my cheque for £20, for remittance to your good father.Captain Elisha Ely Morgan(?1805-64), CD's friend. CD paid W.D. Morgan £20 on 23 March 1863 (CD’s account, Coutts’s Bank). If he will kindly undertake (as you suggest he will) to provide the boy with money according to his – your father’s – discretion, I shall have a far higher reliance on its being a sound one in such a case, than I should have upon the soundness of my own. Nor should I think of questioning the expedience and advantage of any drafts that your father‘He’ cancelled; ‘your father’ added over caret. might draw upon me, if he were satisfied that they were to Frank’s real advantage.
